results.content:
Very Nice course! I have been practicing Salesforce for a while and from this course I have about attachment class, google api and how to get it in visual force page with location marked. 

Section 5 related to REST API Call is very good and nicely structured.  All those codes used in the course are uploaded in github.  Gave 4.5 stars and would have given 5 if REST API are explained with authentication. It was explained only with workbench and it doesn't need any authentication. 

On the whole, it is a good course with a lively content. I have already enrolled for couple of her other courses.
results.content_html:
Very Nice course! I have been practicing Salesforce for a while and from this course I have about attachment class, google api and how to get it in visual force page with location marked.

Section 5 related to REST API Call is very good and nicely structured. All those codes used in the course are uploaded in github. Gave 4.5 stars and would have given 5 if REST API are explained with authentication. It was explained only with workbench and it doesn't need any authentication.

On the whole, it is a good course with a lively content. I have already enrolled for couple of her other courses.

results.content: Seems to be hurried, and this was not a example of real time project, this seems to be just a small starter project with three object, which one does even if we had not attended this. My expectation was high, based on earlier training, was expecting a real life project involving sales,lead,opp etc. this turned out to be big disappointment.
results.content_html: Seems to be hurried, and this was not a example of real time project, this seems to be just a small starter project with three object, which one does even if we had not attended this. My expectation was high, based on earlier training, was expecting a real life project involving sales,lead,opp etc. this turned out to be big disappointment.

results.content:
I am already a Salesfore Developer, but I take courses just to see if I missed anything.  There were a couple of Items that I did know about and that's really the most important thing. If a course just gives me a couple of points that I may have missed, it's worth adding to my tool-belt. This course is great addition to my learning toolsets

Great Job

results.content: Covers fundamental Salesforce concepts.  Information is a bit dated (looks to be from 2016).  The discussions on the REST services is still relevant.
results.content_html: Covers fundamental Salesforce concepts. Information is a bit dated (looks to be from 2016). The discussions on the REST services is still relevant.

results.content: Great course and very useful for someone like me in the process of learning Apex programming. Highly recommended.
results.content_html: Great course and very useful for someone like me in the process of learning Apex programming. Highly recommended.

results.content:
In the beginning, the lecture was ok , but later, the best practices are also violated. 
The examples used is already available in trailhead project module.
Javascript used in visualforce page are not even explained, a person who does not know javascript would not easily understand the course.
Instructor doesn't even replies to the questions asked.

Only part which i found useful was rest api explanation, that too is basic.

results.content: 3.5 stars Because: it would be nice to spend some time on explaining the syntax of the Apex Language. Specifically, the elements that you use in your examples. For instance: I have seen the " := " operator, and a variable name with a ":" in front - what does this mean and where do we go to find this out? The class does not point you to deeper learning material.
results.content_html: 3.5 stars Because: it would be nice to spend some time on explaining the syntax of the Apex Language. Specifically, the elements that you use in your examples. For instance: I have seen the " := " operator, and a variable name with a ":" in front - what does this mean and where do we go to find this out? The class does not point you to deeper learning material.

results.content:
Sorry but did not suit my style. 
Expected to start with foundation that will care take to different levels of existing programming skills, depth in concepts like what is returned and containing what and to what levels as also why bulkification. 
Choose this course to fast track into coding again, but can't get a real move on. Went through Dreamforce videos and that certainly offered me the depth I was looking for.
May be a little more diverse examples could help along with the points above to improve the course.

results.content: Course is an average. Initially the course began well, she had explained the creation of junction-objects, look-up dialogs, etc. very well and nicely, but later as the course progresses, esp. the REST APIs & SOAP APIs there's no explanation of the requirement. What is the requirement for which she's doing a 'GET', what's the requirement for which she's doing a 'POST' etc. are not explained.
results.content_html: Course is an average. Initially the course began well, she had explained the creation of junction-objects, look-up dialogs, etc. very well and nicely, but later as the course progresses, esp. the REST APIs & SOAP APIs there's no explanation of the requirement. What is the requirement for which she's doing a 'GET', what's the requirement for which she's doing a 'POST' etc. are not explained.

results.content: Difficult to understand without proper explanation of what is the purpose of doing what is covered in this course.  For example, very basic, if a user can create a record using the UI, why are we going through the pain of writing these complicated classes and methods, for example to insert record through Workbench, etc.?  Who want to do that, and what is the reason behind going through the pain of coding?  More over, I have no idea whether some of the terms used written on the fly or already exist in the system?  Sorry, I tried my best to get around the contents covered by assuming, but finally the turn out is doubts and confusion!
results.content_html: Difficult to understand without proper explanation of what is the purpose of doing what is covered in this course. For example, very basic, if a user can create a record using the UI, why are we going through the pain of writing these complicated classes and methods, for example to insert record through Workbench, etc.? Who want to do that, and what is the reason behind going through the pain of coding? More over, I have no idea whether some of the terms used written on the fly or already exist in the system? Sorry, I tried my best to get around the contents covered by assuming, but finally the turn out is doubts and confusion!

results.content: She essentially tacked on an overall poorly done REST section to a "Create a Conference App" tutorial that used a Google Maps REST call. Only a third of the class was about REST. She didn't cover the material in depth or even provide links for to source resources to provide references to be able to answer questions in the quiz. She omitted anything about the use of Mocks in Test Classes (essential for this topic). Nothing she included on Test Classes was REST specific. She wrote a trigger at the end, but didn't call a REST service in an @Future call from it like she could have! That was a total waste of time. It belonged in a class on learning Apex. Nearly all of the course was watching her copy/paste code as she spoke very quickly. With the exception of the portion on Wrappers, the remainder could have been learned for free on Trailhead with more complete and better explanations.
results.content_html: She essentially tacked on an overall poorly done REST section to a "Create a Conference App" tutorial that used a Google Maps REST call. Only a third of the class was about REST. She didn't cover the material in depth or even provide links for to source resources to provide references to be able to answer questions in the quiz. She omitted anything about the use of Mocks in Test Classes (essential for this topic). Nothing she included on Test Classes was REST specific. She wrote a trigger at the end, but didn't call a REST service in an @Future call from it like she could have! That was a total waste of time. It belonged in a class on learning Apex. Nearly all of the course was watching her copy/paste code as she spoke very quickly. With the exception of the portion on Wrappers, the remainder could have been learned for free on Trailhead with more complete and better explanations.

results.content: After some initial Trailhead training, I wanted more hands-on exposure and try-out creating a real application. This course by Deepika is a very good tutorial, it sticks to the essence and is clear and efficient. It requires some update from Salesforce Classic to Salesforce Lightning, but that is not hindering me in learning the essential skills and reproducing the examples. Very good stuff, worth the money ! Please update the course for Salesforce Lightning, as less experienced people may be hindered by that.
results.content_html: After some initial Trailhead training, I wanted more hands-on exposure and try-out creating a real application. This course by Deepika is a very good tutorial, it sticks to the essence and is clear and efficient. It requires some update from Salesforce Classic to Salesforce Lightning, but that is not hindering me in learning the essential skills and reproducing the examples. Very good stuff, worth the money ! Please update the course for Salesforce Lightning, as less experienced people may be hindered by that.

results.content:
The way of project explanation is good, but what I feel is.. if you have given more modules/functionality in the project it would be better, 'coz I feel the "Conference Management Application" project is very small and the REST/Trigger/Test concepts are not interlinked with project, it's out of Project.

We could not include this project in my resume, 'coz the CMA project is very small. 

Better you can choose one big module of the project and start to explain from scratch development to Production.

I appreciate your service and the way of project explanation is excellent. Thanks!

results.content: Deepika Khanna does a good job, but she is not very thorough. In almost every session there is a little glitch, she doesn't use the right word to explain something, the name of references will not be consistent or she will announce something that is incorrect. You can almost always figure it out, but it's annoying. The section on the Apex language and VisualForce is flown over too quickly while the section on the REST API is almost overkill in terms of details, she needs to find a better balance. Her english needs some polishing up.
results.content_html: Deepika Khanna does a good job, but she is not very thorough. In almost every session there is a little glitch, she doesn't use the right word to explain something, the name of references will not be consistent or she will announce something that is incorrect. You can almost always figure it out, but it's annoying. The section on the Apex language and VisualForce is flown over too quickly while the section on the REST API is almost overkill in terms of details, she needs to find a better balance. Her english needs some polishing up.

results.content: Deepika is a natural teacher who understand how to take a project from the basic foundations to a level of inspiring complexity. I work in Virginia and Deepika is already quite well respected in my office as people have taken her courses and benefited greatly.
